bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, September 8, 1947

div1.p: With the help of Lawrence Reed, Truby saw the room where Walter Reed died. He notes that he saw old friends in Washington, and they all look distinctly older than 5 years earlier. Truby encloses a sketch locating the surgery and Lazear's house.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, September 8, 1947

opener.dateline:
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, California
Sept. 8/47

div1.p:
Mrs Truby and I had a
wonderful 2 1/2 months stay in
the East-Maryland, Washington, Phila.
and Western New York state- We both
enjoyed it immensely and it made me
do unusual stunts much to my benefit.

Everything went as planned except my
visit with you much to my regret.

However I accomplished one thing I
wanted to do with you found the room
thatwhere Walter Reed died. I took Lawrence
Reed with me and he has all the hope-

At first I was quite bewildered, for the
up stairs corridors were not as I had
pictured them but after walking through
the the various rooms I found one which
had the door & window in the right place
but seemed too small. Upon careful inspection
we found that a temporary partition had been
put in which made the room smaller. Then
I was sure we had the right room. Gen. R.
has all the necessary info. for you and
will show you the room when you go
to Washington.

I will inclose the pictures which Maj. Gilhus
showed me two days before he died. They
probably can't be reproduced but they will
be most instructive to you in several ways.
I have attalched notes but the remarks in
pencil are were all made by Gilhus. The sketch
was a surprise to me as I had not seen
that until I went to see Mrs Gilhus a week
or so ago. With it it seems easy to figure out
how the “Surgery” & other shacks were move as
I have tried to indicate on the back of
G's sketch. I am sure you will be pleased
with the pictures eventhough they are badly faded-

I had a grand visit with old friends in
Washington. Kean, Ireland, Lawrence Reed & Siler were
all fine but distinctly older than when I was
there in '42. I had that drink with dear old
Ranny Kean and we had two nice visits together
but no time to talk of y f.

I hope you got that little building in Cuba
taken care of. Probably you have been down
there. Hope you got my letter at Allantic City (Ame)
suggesting that you see Dr Strade. I am sure
he would help-
